page.title: 17LOCAL BEAUTY SPOT
page.content:
The view across the River Thames from Clifton Hampden parish church is much photographed. The church is situated on a rocky spur which rises quite steeply above the river. Looking upstream the dominant foreground feature is the bridge across the river. This bridge was built in the 1860's to replace the ferry which had, until then, conveyed travellers across the river. John Casey, the last ferryman, built the bridge himself from bricks baked on Clifton Heath. He then became the first toll keeper.
Although the bridge was freed from tolls in 1947 and both the bridge and Bridge House, the old toll house, now belong to the Local Authority descendants of John Casey still live in Bridge House.
